climbs.name: Trundle of Joy
climbs.fa: Chris Miller, Kelly Cordner, Mike Forcash  Late 90's

content.description: Easy climbing past flakes to jug followed by technical 12a crux and  11c layback.
Fun sport route up a semi-arete with a thin crack on the inside right wall.  Simple, yet fun climbing.

This fun route climbs easy, runout slab from the one bolt anchor to the first protection bolt on less than stellar rock.  A fall before clipping that first bolt would have dire consequences!  It may be possible to place a small cam or two before clipping the first bolt.

Using a locking draw on that first bolt would be a wise choice.

Continue past 5 more bolts to the chain anchor.  At this point the climbing is quite fun, edges, pockets, and better rock quality.  The crux is around the 5th/6th bolt.  Staying left is a bit easier.
content.protection:
Six bolts, one belay bolt at the start, chain anchor on top.  Possible small cams, but we didn't use any.  They may not help much...

Make sure the second is tied in or that there is a knot in the end of the rope!!!
content.location: This route is on left side of the slab around the corner to the right of 'Hot Pink Socks.'  From 'Hot Pink Socks' contour down then up along the base trending NW.  After about 40' or so work your way slightly up and left on a narrow ledge to a bolt.  This is a single bolt belay, about 35' off the deck.

content.description: Climb up easy slab to the first (two bolts) bolt.  A fall before clipping the first bolt would not be good.  From there follow really fun and varied climbing to the anchor.  The crux is getting from the last bolt to the anchor.
content.protection: 8 bolts, open hook anchor, 2nd should be tied in or there should be a knot in the rope.
content.location: This is the route to the right of 'Stay Hungry.'

climbs.name: Posers on the Rig
climbs.fa: Hank Means, Scott Ayers, Mike Strassman

content.description: An obvious, usually chalked seam left of O Henry! The seam is strenuous, but the arete keeps the difficulty moderate. The crux is rocking onto the arete...
content.protection: 6 bolts with bolted anchor equipped for lowering.

climbs.name: O Henry!
climbs.fa: Scott Ayers, Hank Means & Mike Strassman 1992

content.description: A bouldery undercling move starts things off, leading to a kinda scary second bolt clip. At the horizontal break it is possible to traverse right to a shake and then go up and back left, but it is easier just to continue up the flake/crack.  Either way, the crux is surmounting the bulge.  Easier face climbing leads to a balancy move to gain the anchors.
Low-angled crack to arÃªte with the crux at bolt 12.
content.protection: 13 bolts, beefy hook anchors. Use a 70m rope.

content.description: Start on the face to the left of the corner - a couple hard moves off the ground to set you up for a big dyno. Stick the jug and proceed up moderate climbing in a somewhat dirty corner to the roof. Climb out the right side of the roof on good holds to a tricky mantle move pulling the lip of the roof. Finish with thoughtful slab/face climbing for a few more bolts to the anchors.
content.location: Left side of the All you Can Eat cliff.

content.description: Start up the crack and make an awkward move around a bulge in the crack to gain easier climbing up to a finishing steep section.

Looking up from the base one can draw the conclusion that the route was appropriately named. Bouldery and somewhat awkward moves lead past the crux at the second to third bolt.  There are still some interesting moves on the slab above and one may feel that the natural line is a bit to the right.
content.location: The route between Carnubiator and Hot Pink Socks.

climbs.name: Crotalus Challenge (extension)
climbs.fa: K. Cordner, D. Pedersen, T. Otto.

content.description: Climb Crotalusly Challenged and continue up left. The cruxes are below and above the 12th bolt.
content.location: A single pitch including Crotalusly Challenged.

content.description: Follow a left trending crack to what may feel like a high first bolt for the beginner leader. The climb then works up and left using the obvious crack system. A big lie back flake gets you to the anchors.
content.location: Easiest looking climb in the middle of the All You Can Eat Wall.

content.description: Locked in a corner with plenty of rest, this high quality climb is popular as the crowds do attest.

The start is kinda forced, but climb up passed the initial bolt to a stance on the left of the slab.

From the stance the climbing improves a lot, and provides something not often found in the gorge.

Step up right onto the slab and follow it with pleasant moves passing the the line of bolts up to the anchors.
content.location: Right of center of the wall.

content.description: Climb a thin, winding crack that opens up wider as you ascend.   Use the ample face holds and jam opportunities.
